events.target_title: Have an explicit system-log-out, system-reboot symbolic icon

note.body:
Hi @jimmac, thanks for your answer and for adding `system-log-out`. 

`system-reboot` isn't used because it doesn't exist, but it would if it existed because there are use cases. For example [in the restart dialog](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/js/ui/endSessionDialog.js#L112) of GNOME Shell, where `view-refresh` had to be used because it didn't exist. 

Also, it would be useful for others outside of GNOME, because Adwaita is the fallback for many themes and the default in many distros. Many themes already have it, but not Adwaita. I think it's not an icon for a crazy idea. At least include it as a symlink to `view-refresh` so that it isn't missing (?).

events.target_title: Broken icon inheritance
Broken icon inheritance

note.body:
This is kind of a mix of an issue with Gtk and GLib I guess.

Previously, when you created a named icon, if it didn't exist in the current icon theme, it would look in the one it inherits from until it was found or it reached the default theme (if it didn't exist at the end it was transparent). Now it's the same, but if it turns out that if there is a symbolic version of the icon in the current theme, that is what will be shown instead of looking back up to the default theme.

For example, if the current theme has `utilities-terminal-symbolic` but doesn't have `utilities-terminal`, the symbolic icon will be shown instead of the icon from Adwaita, which is not the intended behavior.

events.target_title: Broken icon inheritance

note.body:
>  [...] the symbolic version of an icon (while the regular was queried but is absent) in the same theme may keep a more consistent style than  using a regular icon in an unknown theme.

Actually not. Having a mixture of coloured icons mixed with white shapes doesn't make any sense when there is a very similar icon that would make its way unnoticed.

> its not fixable, like so many things in icon themes. 

It is fixable, doing what was done in that commit after the inheritance, I'm not sure if that's here or in Gtk. For example if the icon is null after all, try with the symbolic name.

> If you want a particular icon, make sure it is available, and don't rely on random icon themes to provide it.

That is exactly what I did, but some themes overriding the symbolic version messed everything and make impossible the use of the proper icon. Applications don't care about the icon appearance besides if it's full colour or symbolic, and if it's potentially missing provide a fallback. But now that doesn't work.

Finally, I must say that inheritance is the intended behaviour.

Jehan is right: I don't get a stack trace, I just get "segmentation fault (core dumped)  flatpak run org.gimp.GIMP", and I get the same thing from any flatpak I try to run under Stretch, so it's not specific to GIMP.

The version I had natively on stretch was 0.8.9, and when I asked on #flatpak on freenode they were horrified that Debian used a version so old and known to be buggy, and suggested I get 0.11.7 from stretch-backports, along with the version of ostree in backports. I tried that but still get the same seg fault, so the old version wasn't the problem. 

flatpak gimp does work for me on debian testing; it's just stable/stretch where flatpak always crashes.

events.target_title: User plugins fail to load in user config directory on Linux

note.body: I have a branch where pygimp is back in the build, but that doesn't help because it still uses python2 and pygtk. To get it to work with GTK3 with gobject introspection, we'll need to rewrite the extension for python3. I've looked into this a bit and have a small start on it, but it looks like it's going to be a big job -- Python changed the extension API quite a bit between Python2 and Python3, and the porting guides I've found aren't very complete (many of them suggest rewriting the extension in Cython as an easier solution). If anyone who knows anything about Python extensions wants to help out, please speak up!

events.target_title: User plugins fail to load in user config directory on Linux

note.body: You're right -- I was under the impression that python2 didn't work with GTK3 and GIO, but it turns out that's wrong. (Whew!) Rewriting pygimp for GTK3/GIO is still a substantial project but much more manageable than updating pygimp to python3.

events.target_title: Ensure that the initial lock completes, even if there is a motion event.
Moving the mouse Immediately after locking prevents screen standby

note.body:
Ahh - looks like this is a feature: You don't want to emit the active event while the screen is fading: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/js/ui/screenShield.js#L1298 - the comment suggests that firing the event forces the screen to blank.

That's fine - but this conflicts with the case where the user has attempted to unlock the screen and failed. In that situation you start to reset the lock screen but if there is further input from the user you abort so they can enter input again.

I've proposed a fix that ensures that the initial lock always completes. WDYT?

events.target_title: Moving the mouse Immediately after locking prevents screen standby

note.body:
Thanks for picking this up - it's been a while!

Usually when you lock the screen the following should happen:
 * Screen is locked
 * Screen fades to black
 * `LockedHint` event is sent on the dbus

If you lock the screen but generate a mouse movement during the fades-to-black phase the following happens:
 * Screen is locked
 * Screen fade is interupted
 * *No `LockedHint` event is sent*

The real problem is the `LockedHint` dbus event. If you're writing an app that needs to know if the screen is locked or not it's important that these `LockedHint` events are sent accurately.

My fix catches the case described above.

@verdre - does that explain things?

events.target_title: New g_str_get_substr as g_strstr_len alternative
New g_str_get_substr as g_strstr_len alternative

note.body:
Thank you for your comment.
1. We need such a function in our code base because we end up in a situation where we need to search for a substring in a region of memory where we don't know if it contains text or binary data. Details, if you are interested: we are implementing a client that receives messages from the network. Messages contain a text-based header, followed by binary data. We look for the end of the header with `g_strstr_len`. However, if because of a faulty network or other reasons, the end of header is missing, we end up searching for it in binary data, which is very likely to contain the null byte, and hence causes a premature end of the search. (we would have like the search to continue so we can go to the next message). Since of issue 159, I assumed there was a need for such a feature, hence the PR.

2. I agree that putting this function in the str utils "module" may not be the best fit. The intent of this function is to operate on any arbitrary memory, not on strings. I would have liked something that explicitly deals with raw memory instead of strings (like `g_bytes_search` or `g_mem_search`), but then there was no utility files for them. Would you have some other modules/files where this function (properly renamed) would be a better fit?

events.target_title: [Icon View] Default sort order settings not honored (+ no docs + no UI)
[Icon View] Default sort order settings not honored (+ no docs + no UI)

note.body:
Hi António -- thanks for the response --

Sorry, I am using different machine today than the one I was reporting on originally. But *it's not just limited to the list view*, and this retitling makes the bug no longer what I am reporting. I am talking about the *default* sort order, not folder-specific sort orders (I don't care about those).

I may have confused version 3.26 with 3.28. Sorry about that.

Reproduced against `nautilus` 3.30.0-1 from the current Debian `testing` distribution. Bug is not present in `nautilus` 3.26.3.1-1 out of an old Debian testing, or in my rebuilds. I cannot get a 3.28 to test with from <https://deb.debian.org/debian/pool/main/n/nautilus/> right now, unfortunately.

## Better test script

```sh
#!/bin/sh
# Test script for the default sort order regression in 3.30.
# Works with Nautilus 3.26 - 3.30.

# Kill any existing Nautilus processes
killall nautilus

# Nuke Nautilus's global settings (but not the per-folder ones?)
gsettings reset-recursively org.gnome.nautilus

# I like reverse-chronological order best.
# Let's make that the defaults.
gsettings set org.gnome.nautilus.preferences default-sort-in-reverse-order true
gsettings set org.gnome.nautilus.preferences default-sort-order mtime

# Make a never-visited-before folder and go there.
# This won't have any per-folder settings associated with it.
# So Nautilus should use its defaults.
cd `mktemp -d`

# Make some files to view
touch -t 197907060000 seventies
touch -t 198312240000 eighties
touch -t 199701010000 nineties

# Show Nautilus here.
nautilus . </dev/null >/dev/null 2>/dev/null &
```

## Expected behaviour (3.26)

With this script, I expect the icons view to list the files in reverse chronological order: `nineties`, `eighties`, `seventies`. A rebuild of Debian `nautilus` 3.26.3.1-1 from its `.dsc` shows this behaviour:

![expected-3.26-behaviour](/uploads/0f2153679bbad41647b637f7fd464397/expected-3.26-behaviour.png)

## Regression (3.30)

Running the script again when Nautilus 3.30 is installed from the current Debian `testing`:

![unexpected-3.30-behaviour](/uploads/844a0f3840a727f6970cb93f6f34827e/unexpected-3.30-behaviour.png)

The files are now shown in alphabetical order: `eighties`, `nineties`, `seventies`.

events.target_title: Please add UI for changing and using the default sort order

note.body:
My totally unreasonable opinion: since it's a choice between list view and icon view only at present, and since those views basically do the same thing, then I'm in favour of everything having the same single sort order and view choice. If you change the view choice or sort order in one window, it should immediately update in all other windows too. List view sort order should be the same as icon view sort order. **Fancy views (music albums, revision timeline, disk usage, phylo tree, movie collection, ...) belong in other apps**. Nautilus is all about files and folders. Simplify its model radically, and do away with the fussiness! Thunar gets it right! :hammer\_and\_pick: :smiling\_imp:

-------

In the meantime though, if it has to be the default+override model, I'd like the per-folder behaviour to be:

* **Opt-in** - make it clearer that the override is an override.
* **Recursively applied** - if I change a parent folder's overrides, that view should propagate down the tree unless overridden by a deeper folder.

-------

Perhaps a single line switcher in the menu that flips a folder between "Standard" and "Custom" states would be even more minimal? It could affect both view and sort order, if that's what's wanted. The risk of that is that you'd only have a single toolbar button controlling the view, and it wouldn't be obvious what its meaning would be unless you looked in the menu dropdown next to it.

events.target_title: authentication dialog does not allow selecting the admin user

note.body:
Hi


> verdre <https://gitlab.gnome.org/verdre> commented:
>
> So what's the usecase for this? Isn't it enough that the command gets
> executed as root in the end?
>

We work in a computer lab. Any one of three admins (A, B, C), or
combination of them may be doing a class with students,
which might include a task that needs sudo, one day formatting a USB,
another day something else, and when sudo
password prompt pops up admins B and C cannot type in their passwords, only
A can and A might not be there.

I see the comment about this being insecure, but we are teaching sysadm or
linux installation,
and there is a level of trust necessary in any case.

There are some workarounds like using polkit or sudo to allow all users to
passwordless format disks, for example,
but many other programmes also use the lab and we don't want to change it
before and after every class, nor
have a specific user list having that capability permanently.

Regards,
Jan

—

note.body:
The use case for a mailing list is completely different.
I'm reading-only the mails of my wife and she's reading-only my mails. Reading-only should not change the read-status as this would make my own mail read and probably missed. Additionally the read-status of the other accounts provides the information that the other party has read it.
In business environments more advanced servers like Exchange can deal with shared folders and account-based read-status, IMAP can't do that.
I don't think using a mailing list for this kind of situations is the right way.

Just thought about that feature per account, because I have seen that on some other mail client and used it for this case. Can't remember which client, maybe Android K-9...

This work-around would mean a lot of duplicated mails, filtering and forwarding:
Party A SMTP is configured to forward all incoming mails to something like forwarded_A@party_B.de. On the mail server on party B there is a filter moving all mails sent to forwarded_A to s subfolder forwarded_A, having it's own mirror with deleting, read-status and so on... And the same setup the other way round from B to A, both have a mirrored incoming folder of the other party.

events.target_title: Implement OpenVPN 2.4 Compression Options
Implement OpenVPN 2.4 Compression Options

note.body:
That table looks largely correct, but I think the real way forward would be to change the UI to have ``Compression: [dropdown |v]``, with options for "automatic", "lzo", and "lz4".

I ended up working around this issue by changing the server config to look at supported client compression schemes at connection and change compression on the fly to the best supported option. This is possible with openvpn 2.4. This is why I suggest the term "automatic", though "default" might also be acceptable.

This brings up an issue with the "no" option in the table. Not specifying ``--compress`` doesn't disable compression. It simply uses what the server sets.

events.target_title: Implement OpenVPN 2.4 Compression Options

note.body:
>  I think I've done exactly that? What should've been different?

I replied without having tried your WIP. I didn't get the impression from the comments here that you had put in a drop-down like that. Cool!

>  There's a checkbox on the left -- unsetting it means "no".

That should be even clearer than "automatic" or "default". Thumbs up here, too.

>  My understanding is that `--compress` without an argument allows the server to set the compression?

In my experimentation, the option on its own does nothing, and the server is always free to set an option. As mentioned, new in 2.4 is that on connection the client sends a list of capabilities and the server can do whatever. This is why the manual says "allowing a different setting to be pushed later."

GIMP 2.10.2 writing to incorrect IPTC metadata tag DateCreated
GIMP 2.10.2 writing to incorrect IPTC metadata tag DateCreated

note.body:
The problem is that GIMP is writing to fields that should be used for the date when the photo was taken and is causing the loss of the original date. 

I don't know if there is a requirement for GIMP to write any metadata at all when an image is changed.  Just don't write over existing data, and don't remove any data that already exists in the image prior to GIMP making a change. 

If the development team has a design requirement for GIMP to update metadata when an image is modified, then the fields I mentioned are suggestions:

*  Iptc:DigitalCreationDate
*  Iptc:DigitalCreationTime 
*  xmp-xmp:ModifyDate

But if there is no design requirement to update metadata, then just don't write any metadata fields, and don't remove any metadata fields.  In other words, the metadata after GIMP updated the photo would be the same as the metadata before GIMP updated the photo. 

The GIMP design team would need to make a decision as to what metadata, if any, GIMP should be updating.

events.target_title: Complete GUADEC map with relevant PoI's

note.body:
Please take a look to the code and running example [here](http://bl.ocks.org/jsanz/1bc2f6a9c998fbc014bc1820dcb2c76d).

![](http://pix.toile-libre.org/upload/original/1528898208.png)

The list of POIs are passed as an array of osm identifiers because some data in OSM can be polygons (ways) we have two lists and two separated calls to retrieve and deal with that data. Check lines [30](https://gist.github.com/jsanz/1bc2f6a9c998fbc014bc1820dcb2c76d#file-index-html-L30) and [34](https://gist.github.com/jsanz/1bc2f6a9c998fbc014bc1820dcb2c76d#file-index-html-L34) for the list of nodes passed.

For example, [Almería University](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/29220363) is a polygon, but most of restaurants and other places are nodes like [this one](https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/4516012525).

Let me know if that looks like something to start with. Mind that the code is a bit dirty and on the cartography side there's a lot that can be done to make the map nicer.

events.target_title: Complete GUADEC map with relevant PoI's

note.body:
@olea I've been working on the styling, interactivity and general user experience but not on the routes yet. I've forked the repo and I'm working on a `map` branch. Let me know if you think I should do a merge-request now. I've also updated [my block](http://bl.ocks.org/jsanz/raw/1bc2f6a9c998fbc014bc1820dcb2c76d/) to be easy to inspect the changes.

![Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/w0BdxQl.png)


Changes:

* I've added an icon, using the gnome footprint, but it's customizable to any PNG served on the same host or any other if CORS is enabled.
* Improved a bit the labelling
* If OSM provides a name in English, it's used instead of the default `name` tag
* Changed to the [CARTO Voyager vector basemap](https://carto.com/location-data-services/basemaps/), which I think it's better for this use case as it highlights better the city features.
* Now it only does a single query to the OSM Overpass API (it's faster)
* You can override OSM properties on the list of nodes or ways, in case you want to put a custom name for the venue or anything not suited to be added to OSM. I've added a couple of examples.
* Added a popup when you click/tap on the points. The pop up uses a white list of properties from the script parameters so you can decide which OSM tags make sense to display. Website, Wikidata and Wikipedia properties are displayed as links and the pop up shows a link to the original OSM data, so it's easy to improve or fix anything you see.

Finally, as you can see on the screenshot, because we are using vector geometries instead of traditional raster tiles, this means that you can rotate and tilt the map, just maintain the `Control` key or pinch if you are on your mobile to play with it.

\o/

events.target_title: Outbox queue should keep sending when message-specific problem occurs
Outbox queue should keep sending when message-specific problem occurs

note.body:
Hey, sorry for the slow reply here (was away on vacation). In this case I don't think that's sufficient - it would be best if the send queue could skip over failing messages and continue sending the non-problematic ones. Otherwise a single stuck message could potentially block a user from using Geary until they figure out the solution is to start deleting messages in their outbox.

(That said, I do think the new notifications would be an improvement, but the application needs to remain usable even if there is a failed message in the queue.)

Expose Diagnostics for Language Servers

note.body:
> It looks like you want the functionality provided by `valac` to invoke a C compiler, but to provide your own front-end instead of `valac`. That's kind of reasonable, although in past I've been advised Vala shouldn't be used as a build system. 

Yes, that's kind of what's happening - when you 'save' the file in the editor, the main program spawns' it'self in 'compiler' mode which runs this code, compiling all the listed files. It then outputs a JSON summary of all the errors/warning etc. that are found, with line numbers.

That is then used to flag the lines of code in the editor that need fixing. 

Another work around for this would just have a 'JSON' output format for valac...

events.target_title: Wrong wiki URL in gThumb
Misc user help issues in gThumb 3.6 (partly due to new gtk3 interface)
Misc user help issues in gThumb 3.6 (partly due to new gtk3 interface)

note.body:
Andre, thanks for your comments. Following are some issues with the documentation. Code issues are below in a separate report. 

Some errors found in the Help file of gThumb 3.6.

Using gThumb 3.6.1 on Xubuntu 18.04/64-bit.

1) Editing Files. "To access the editing tools, open an image and then click the <gui>Edit File</gui> toolbar button (the palette icon)."  
Must be: brush icon

2) "If you exit the editing mode (by pressing <key>Esc</key> or the <gui>View the Folders</gui>toolbar button)..."  
View the folders button? Where? 

3) "To rename the images click on<gui>Rename</gui>."  
Where is Rename? (right mouse / F2 do work)

4) "Enhance Colors  
This tool provides automatic white balance correction. No user adjustments are required."  
So why are there three options? 

The English version of gThumb calls that Adjust Contrast.  
Suggestion: Adjust Contrast.  
This tool provides three ways to enhance the contrast of the photo.

5) Color Adjustments  
Where is Equalize? 

6) "You can enable or disable extensions using <guiseq><gui>Edit</gui><gui>Extensions</gui></guiseq>".  
Must be: Edit-button, Preferences, Extensions

7) Opening an image: "Pressing <key>Escape</key> will exit the viewer mode, and return the user to the browser mode. A toolbar button (<gui>View the folders</gui>) is also provided for this purpose."  
View the folders: does not exist. 

8) "To print the current image in the viewer mode, use <guiseq><gui>File</gui><gui>Print</gui></guiseq>".  
File - Print does not exist; must be Ctrl+P or right-click mouse - Print

9) Help: "<gui>Equalize</gui>".  
This tool provides automatic histogram equalization.  
Does not exist.

10) Help Red eye: "If you are fiendishly clever, love matrix algebra and open source software, please <link href="https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/gthumb/development">submit a patch!</link>  
That page does not exist. Must be .../Apps/Gthumb/dev...

11) "The <gui>Layout</gui> tab provides some additional gThumb -specific options."  
There's no layout tab, though there's an option Layout under Export - Image wall. Is that what is meant?

12) Starting slideshow:  
"or by clicking <guiseq><gui>View</gui><gui>Slideshow</gui></guiseq>."  
Where's that?

13) Help: <guiseq><gui>Edit</gui><gui>Preferences</gui><gui>Slideshow</gui></guiseq>  
Where is Edit? And must be: Edit - Preferences - Viewer

14) Help: "To copy a file in the browser view, use <guiseq><gui>Edit</gui><gui>Copy</gui></guiseq>"  
Edit - Copy does not exist, just say Ctrl+C

15) Please update the screenshots in the Help file to the new dark interface (users can be lost by seeing screenshots that do not match their software). Replace the screenshot in "Browsing your files" (that dates from 2007!) to something that shows 2018.

3) "To set an image as the system desktop wallpaper, right-click on the image and select <guiseq><gui>Set as Desktop Background</gui></guiseq> from the pop-up menu."

events.target_title: Readability of the search results depends on the wallpaper

note.body:
@diegogangl I played with your pen a bit. 25% Brightness looks very muddy to me, so I tried adding some saturation to counteract the darkening. I found that increasing the saturation counteracts that, making it darker while preserving its vibrancy. The following screenshots are useing the pen's 'clouds' bg class.

*100px blur, 25% Brightness* (diegogangl's original pen):
![25_brightness](/uploads/8439c0abcef5a39d10d276a9ac34178a/25_brightness.PNG)

*50px blur, 75% Brightness and 1.75 Saturation (Pen here: https://codepen.io/anon/pen/PgyyOX):*
![75_brightness_with_saturation](/uploads/2fd0ac3def0af8d233ba62f30b5fa12a/75_brightness_with_saturation.PNG)

Here is the 'clouds' bg wihout any filters (for reference):
![without_mods](/uploads/4715b82a7712cfb7c84a4f46bc68607d/without_mods.PNG)

---

If you try the demo and only use blur (without brightness or saturation filter) the resulting image is still a bit darker that the original. As far as I know this is caused by blending colors in the sRGB color space instead of the linearRGB color space. As said in the video linked below, a lot of software uses the simpler approach (sticking to sRGB), which produces muddy, less pleasing images when applying blur.

If blur is a general direction GNOME wants to adapt more (I am also thinking about the lookscreen mockups) maybe this is something worth investigating?

- Video about sRGB vs linearRGB (and ugly blurs), by Minute Physics: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKnqECcg6Gw
- Article: https://ninedegreesbelow.com/photography/linear-gamma-blur-normal-blend.html

events.target_title: Only search in the current folder when using type-ahead

note.body:
Gnome.  You suck.  I don't mean to be sound ignorant, but you keep on forcing "features" on your users.  However, what you really do is remove functionality.

Pressing ctrl+f wasn't hard when I wanted to do a recursive search in a folder.  Now it is the default.  That is fine, but the functionality of type-ahead search/find no longer even exists.  I used this functionality hundreds of times a day.

I avoided distros/DEs where Nautlius was the default because of this.  I installed Nemo, et al. because of this.

Stop doing your user base a favor.  Please give us the functionality we want without having to "trust" random PPAs.

convert PIL.Image to GdkPixbuf, then load into GtkImage -- crash Windows if image too large
convert PIL.Image to GdkPixbuf, then load into GtkImage -- crash Windows if image too large

note.body:
Thanks for the response.

The problem with .new_from_bytes is that, although indeed there are no crashes, it seems to me that it leaks or unnecessarily references memory. Originally, I was using .new_from_bytes in a very straightforward and, I think, correct way. I discovered .new_from_data while trying to address the memory problem. I was doing PIL->GdkPixbuf->GtkImage a large number of times per "session" (animation) for an indefinite number of sessions, and I noticed that memory usage increased by something like 20 MB every 5-to-10 seconds. I felt that somehow it was related to garbage-collection and tried dozens of workarounds, but in each case either I still had the leak or I caused a new gc-related crash. Ultimately, the documentation for .new_from_data suggested that it wouldn't create the same problem, so I switched and everything seemed great.

Do you think this behavior of .new_from_bytes is itself a bug? Do you want me to assemble an Issue about it?

Thanks again.

events.target_title: convert PIL.Image to GdkPixbuf, then load into GtkImage -- crash Windows if image too large

note.body: I think this is one of the many things I tried already, but I will test again in isolation and in the bigger project.

events.target_title: convert PIL.Image to GdkPixbuf, then load into GtkImage -- crash Windows if image too large

note.body:
Ok, it seems my previous experimentation was not as systematic as I thought: replacing the argument with the copy seems to eliminate the memory leak and seems not to introduce any other issues. I tested new_from_bytes/copy in the isolated script on Linux (python3) a few times, and then in the bigger project on both Linux (python3) and Windows (python2). 

Very embarrassing that I did not discover such a tiny change that fixes everything...

Thanks so much!

Applet won't refresh the Wi-Fi list when already connected
Applet won't refresh the Wi-Fi list when already connected

note.body:
I can finally reopen this issue now that I have a clear understanding why I was left with that feeling.
When you are already connected to a wifi network, the network manager applet takes forever (or doesn't try at all) to refresh the wifi list in the applet menu. A clear usecase for this issue would be me using a public wifi and noticing that some site has been blocked by access restrictions. I take out my phone to share the slower network on it. In this case I can't just open the menu and instantly reconnect to the new wifi, instead I have to manually disconnect from the current, reopen the applet menu, wait a second for the wifi list to refresh and then I can connect to the new network.

[Maybe gegl?] Make unsharp mask filter more familiar to the world

note.body: Well, the "unsharp mask", or "unsharp masking" is an universally recognized photographic technique, so I'd certainly keep the name. As for parameters - that's what confuses me a lot in the gegl filter - neither "standard deviation" slider, nor "scale" behave in a familiar way (Std Dev seems to influence amount of sharpening, too. Scale has a very narrow useful range).

note.body: Do not be so trigger-happy in closing this report, because it's not about renaming.

note.body: I would know, I opened the report. It's not about renaming, it's about "reinventing the wheel" with unintuitive parameters.

events.target_title: [Maybe gegl?] Make unsharp mask filter more familiar to the world

note.body:
> Yes and changing the names of the parameters to match the legacy plug-in is inssuficient?

That is, unfortunately, correct. With the new parameters, as I stated in note 251866, the useful range is very narrow, and I really would love to have threshold back, because it does keep noise at bay when sharpening. Basically what I was saying that GEGL USM doesn't behave like one would expect from USM. I will certainly try and tweak the parameters as you suggested. Let's see what happens.

events.target_title: [Maybe gegl?] Make unsharp mask filter more familiar to the world

note.body:
> about threshhold:
when using the new usm it didn't look like it introduces noise anymore (unless you crank up the values to high), but I might be wrong.

Will do examples soon (probably on Monday as I'm preparing for another photographic spree weekend) but as I tested the plug-in, the sky was very grainy on photos treated with new plugin, even with the "default" parameters, and required more aggressive noise reduction, which in turn required more ingenious masking of clouds (read: no longer 6 minutes, but nearly 40 per photo). With old plug in it was easy: just 0.1 radius, amount (depending on the lens) 1.60-1.90 or 3.6-4.0 for RAW, and 2 threshold. With the new plugin I couldn't find a satisfying combination, even with lowest values, because with cranking the Scale grain increased, and with increasing Standard deviation even with low Scale, image got oversharpened pretty quick.

note.body:
If gedit creates or opens a new file, the user must select `tools > Highlight Misspelled Words` each time. Gedit will remember a preference for a file that has *previously* been spellchecked; however, it will not automatically perform spell check on a new file. 

I would expect to be able to make a global setting, so that any file Gedit opens will use the spellchecker.  

Steps: 

1. Open Gedit, select `tools > Highlight Misspelled Words`
2. Create a new file (in my case, a markdown file).

The result is that the setting has not been retained. The user must re-select the option to spell check the document.

events.target_title: WIP: renderer-native: Accept frames without ever blocking

note.body:
The error `gnome-shell[3146]: meta_kms_framebuffer_get_fb_id: assertion 'kms_framebuffer != NULL' failed` happens in `meta_kms_framebuffer_get_fb_id`, because `kms_fb` is `NULL`.

Initially this happens in `meta_gpu_kms_flip_crtc` (meta-gpu-kms.c) when `drmModePageFlip` is called.
And `meta_gpu_kms_flip_crtc` is called in `meta_onscreen_native_flip_crtc` (meta-renderer-native.c) in the switch case where the mode `META_RENDERER_NATIVE_MODE_GBM` is assumed.

So basically it fails, because mutter seems to assume that the secondary gpu always uses GBM instead of EGLStreams.

note.body:
The next steps would be:
1) Make it run without an install.
2) Wrap it up into a zip file.

Making it run is usually just setting up some environment variables so that all the components can find themselves and each other. I don't know cx_Freeze but it should be able to tell you what it's doing; stuff like "put it into the Start menu" and "put it on the desktop" are unwanted, some stuff may be unnecessary, and the rest can be put into a script (if meld is a Python script then writing Python code for that is probably the path of least annoyance).
You need to decide whether that script would be part of meld itself or a separate script that calls the meld executable. The former is usually easier on the users, the latter may or may not be easier on the developers.

Step 2 is trivial :-)

note.body:
> How would that work? How would you expect it to work? There are LaTeX commands and one file could have many source files.

With regard to expectations, I wouldn't expect it to produce accurate counts for arbitrary user-defined (`\newcommand`-defined) code, but I would expect it to follow includes and `\input` files and exclude formatting commands, etc.

I would *not* expect the Gnome LaTeX team to do this if it requires writing this code from scratch, but I would hope that we could leverage existing libraries to do so.

> Why is using a word count feature in the application used to open the resulting output file (e.g. a PS or PDF file) not sufficient?

The biggest reason for me is the feedback loop: when you're dealing with a long document, it's a pain if you have to recompile repeatedly to get the wordcount.

I would also expect that a library which parses the (La)TeX input would be able to produce more accurate counts than a PDF viewer could, since it can differentiate tables and labels, etc, from running text and has the original words *before* they get split across multiple lines at syllable boundaries (i.e. I expect systematic over-counting from a PDF-based wordcount).

events.target_title: GNetworkMonitor wrong when offline and NetworkManager connectivity checker enabled

note.body:
I think that the problem with the Connectivity property of NetworkManager (tested on Fedora 29, nm 1.12.6) in the way it is used by GNetworkMonitor is that:
*  a device disconnection doesn't trigger a new connection check immediately, leaving the state to "FULL" until the next regular scheduled check (300 seconds by default in Fedora).
* a curl connection timeout of 20 seconds is added, causing a supplementary delay when the conncheck url is not available.
* when not network is available, a conncheck can usually fail with a curl status 6 (hostname of the url cannot be resolved), or by a connection timeout (if the url is provided with an IP address), and for what I noticed, in such cases, the Connectivity property is set to LIMITED and not to NONE as expected.

My feeling is that GNetworkMonitorNM should also query the State property, which immediately reflects a network state modification, and use the combination of State and Connectivity to build the GNetworkMonitor internal state, Connectivity being just the way to detect captive portal situations.

Thanks for your quick reply.

events.target_title: Tesseract 4 beta support - Orientation detection failure

Not all bugs : I only suggest that this specific feature is particularly prone to fail with very annoying consequences, and at the same time adds very little value.

May I suggest that, at least, when the fast and reliable way to detect the orientation is not working, the fallback is to trust the user instead of using the slow and unreliable method (which is worse than drawing an orientation at random, btw) ?

ps: I'm reopening the issue because the question shifted a bit, not because I want to have the last word. Thanks for your time.

events.target_title: Tesseract 4 beta support - Orientation detection failure

note.body:
I was thinking once (on the first error) for the session:
- if the user is ok without orientation detection, he will select "keep on", and eveything will proceed as usual, except for orentation detection, until he closes openpaperwork
- if the user want to have orientation detection, he will have to choose "stop". He'll have the warning until he chooses "keep on" or until he fixes the problem.

The only problem I see with this approach is that people that cannot or do not want to fix the problem and that do not care about orientation detection will complain about this modal warning each time they start openpaperwork and scan something. They will ask for a way to automatically acknowledge the fact they want to keep on, which is almost equivalent to the suggestion of making possible to deactivate orientation detection :] . But maybe I'm anticipating a bit too much.

note.body:
It should probably say, Because this image uses features from GIMP 2.10, the xcf file can't be read by older programs.

The nonsense about metadata should be deleted - if gimp 2.8 and earlier can't read the file they for sure won't show the metadata.

events.target_title: 'Save this image with XCF file with better but slower compression . .': unintelligible English

note.body:
i'm sorry if i wasn't clear. For sure people should be warned about data loss. i was trying to say that in the case the xcf file can't be read by older versions of gimp there is no point mentioning that the metadata won't show up, since the whole image won't show up :) The dialogue is not offering a choice to save in some backward-compatible format; today, the code isn't there to do that. Worse, i don't think there' any way to do it in general and to meet people's likely expectations - there isn't a way to simulate the new layer modes in older versions, so such layers would have to be flattened. Instead, the dialogue is trying to say, This image can't be saved compatibly. Separately, it's asking something inscrutable about compression. I think the choices are,
(1) This image can be saved in a way that can be read by older versions of GIMP;
however, you can choose a better compression if you like, but then older versions of GIMP won't read the file. In either case, older versions of GIMP won't read the new metadata format.
or,
(2) This image uses new features and can't be saved in a way that can be read by older versions of GIMP.

events.target_title: Rotation makes the image blurred

note.body:
In Tool Options, which interpolation method are you using? Since GIMP is a bitmap editor, not a vector editor like Inkscape, when you rotate an image by other than a multiple of 90 degrees, GIMP has to invent values for pixels that are "inbetween the cracks".

One mitigation is to resize the image 300% (3 times bigger on each side), rotate, and scale down, but that's similar to using NoHalo or LoHalo in practice.

Another (which is what most image editor tutorials suggest) is to apply shaperpening at the end of all your editing, but watch that this can affect colour values.

I usually compare different versions of an application source code. The source code folder has hundreds of source code files and dozens of folders. When I use merge to compare two source code trees, meld expands everything, and I can't focus on the files I want to compare. I am not affected by this bug, but still want to chime in. I understand the reasoning behind switching to Harfbuzz, dropping the use of Freetype for font loading, and thus losing support for PCF and BDF fonts.

events.target_title: two-finger scrolling is far too fast

note.body:
I have reported exactly the same bug as https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libinput/libinput/issues/252, and it was closed as "wontfix because it is not a bug in libinput". So, continuing here.

As promised in the libinput bug, here is some experimental analysis on a GNOME session on Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro laptop. This laptop has a display with 3200x1800 resolution, so HiDPI. All GNOME settings have been reset to defaults (by creating a new user), except for the monospace font (Source Code Pro 10), showing hidden files in Nautilus (otherwise I would run out of the scroll bar), and for disabling "natural" scroll direction. Notepadqq was set to use Source Code Pro 13, the difference is because they use different units for font sizes, points vs pixels. The lie about touchpad size described in the libinput issue has been reverted. Libinpit version is 1.14.2.

The following tests were made:

1. Open this page in Chromium. Scroll to the very end. Scroll up exactly one touchpad height by using two-finger scrolling. See how many times one needs to press PageDown to reach the end.

2. Same test in Firefox.

3. Same test in Firefox, but with MOZ_USE_XINPUT2=1.

4. Open Nautilus with my home folder, scroll down all the way. Scroll up exactly one touchpad height by using two-finger scrolling. See how many times one needs to press PageDown to reach the end.

5. Open dmesg.txt in GEdit. Scroll down using two fingers by the full touchpad height. See which line number is on top. There are 44 lines per page.

6. Open dmesg.txt in notepadqq (which is a simple Qt5-based editor), with QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland if testing on wayland. Scroll down using two fingers by the full touchpad height. See which line number is on top. There are 45 lines per page.

All tests were repeated 4 times: (nw) native resolution on Wayland, (nx) native resolution on Xorg, (lw) 1600x900 resolution on Wayland, (lx) 1600x900 resolution on Xorg.

Results:

1. (nw) 5, (nx) 3.2, (lw) 5, (lx) 3.
2. (nw) 5, (nx) 3.5, (lw) 5, (lx) 3.5.
3. (nw) 5, (nx) 3.5, (lw) 5, (lx) 3.5.
4. (nw) 13.5, (nx) 8.5, (lw) 13.5, (lx) 9.5.
5. (nw) 317, (nx) 211, (lw) 302, (lx) 203.
6. (nw) 213, (nx) 164, (lw) 217, (lx) 158.

(of course, as a former physicist, I should have repeated each measurement at least 3 times to get the error margin, but it's too boring, so let's assume that "3 vs 3.5" is within the experimental error margin)

So, conclusions:

1. HiDPI or not HiDPI, it's the same scrolling experience on a given windowing platform and toolkit.

2. GTK scrolls text faster than Qt by a factor of approximately 1.5, both on X11 and Wayland.

3. Wayland consistently scrolls faster than X11 by a factor of 1.3-1.5, on both toolkits.

The phrase "on both toolkits" suggests that some part of the issue is outside of them.

Also note that my initial complaint in the libinput bug applied to a Xorg-based system.

events.target_title: two-finger scrolling is far too fast

note.body:
Just another data point, the old and unmaintained `xf86-input-synaptics` driver, on my hardware, with the default settings, produces faster scrolling than `xf86-input-libinput`. Both tests with Firefox yield 5 PageDowns as a result of their measurement.

What's surprising about this data point is that we got this bug report now, when libinput (which is supposedly slower) is the king, and not 10 years ago. Did the hardware change in some non-obvious way? Or maybe it's because the synaptics driver had the scroll speed configurable (like everything else, whether it makes sense or not), and the affected people could just fix it locally via xorg.conf snippets? Or, as yet another hypothesis (most likely the case for me), it is something else about the scroll events, not just the raw speed (e.g. a worse implementation of the hysteresis filter), that upsets the reporter? @ssfrr could you please retest with the old driver?

For me, the main complaints about libinput-based scrolling is high sensitivity to finger tremor, and the fact that it is too easy (without lying about the size or being extra careful) to trigger an unwanted extra bit of scroll (sometimes even kinetic!) by just lifting the fingers off the touchpad. To elaborate on the second point: when I end the scroll-up gesture, the skin on my finger is stretched a bit (because the touchpad is rough), and it snaps when I lift the finger off. The touchpad can register this "snap" as a very short period of very fast vertical movement. Alternatively, it registers spurious movement when finger pressure changes, because the position of the center indeed changes slightly.

events.target_title: Support PAN GlobalProtect VPN
implement HTTP 2.0

note.body:
Is there any news on this?

HTTP/2 is pretty widespread at this point (even the built in HTTP client in Windows 10 used by Windows Explorer for mounting WebDAV shares supports HTTP/2), so I'm really hoping libsoup can join the party.

I'm particularly interested in libsoup supporting HTTP/2 so that gvfs will use HTTP/2 for WebDAV. HTTP/2 was specifically designed to speed up the case where there are many small requests as is the case with HTML, CSS, and Javascript. Therefore, I strongly suspect that it would also speed up WebDAV with its many small requests (PROPFIND, LOCK, PROPPATCH, etc).

note.body: Who cares what the mount point is?  If I don't want a label, my software should not say "yes you do"; it should do as I say.

events.target_title: Don't require a volume label

note.body: I wouldn't bother taking the time to remove it afterwards because I don't care whether it is there or not.  What I don't like is being forced to take the time and spend the mental energy thinking of something to put in the box in the first place, especially when it is completely unnecessary.  Why is having the box there not enough?  Why do you feel that users must be **forced** to choose a name?  Don't you think that most users who don't know either way will tend to put in a name just because there is a prompt there for it?  And will there really be harm if they don't?  This is a balance decision, and what you are balancing is the potential harm if someone does not put in a name against the, what I would argue to be user abuse against those who know they don't need or want a name.  The amount of harm I can see to a novice user skipping the label and hitting next anyway is very small, so it just does not balance against the user abuse side in my view.

events.target_title: Unmount broken
Unmount broken

note.body: Nevermind, it still doesn't work on the right disk.  While the disk is not mounted initially, by the time unuse_data_iterate() is called, it has been mounted for some reason.  I'm thinking there is a race condition where something mounts the fs temporarily and unmounts it, and during the time it is mounted is when unuse_data_iterate() is called, which sees it is mounted, and tries to unmount it, but by the time the unmount request goes through, it has already been unmounted.
